panel-1.panelText: While in reflection we look back at emotions, thoughts, and actions, discipline is about how we control them in the moment. Discipline is not to be confused with punishment. Meaning “to teach”… where in self-discipline means we become our own teacher.

panel-2.panelText: Self-discipline ties in closely with the choices we make, well cover that in detail in another lesson.

panel-3.panelText: Integrity has a shared trait as well. How you act when no one is watching is a test of your character.

panel-4.panelText: There are a lot of little things every day that we don’t want to do, but we must do. Buckle down, monitor your emotions, thoughts, and actions… align with your destiny.

panel-1.panelText: Productivity: The ability to get tasks done or solve problems efficiently. Planning and preparation are related as they help you understand what your priorities are, and what needs to get done.

panel-2.panelText: Over the chessboard, this can take many forms. It can mean getting your pieces developed or launching an attack. In other scenarios it might also mean defending a piece or your position, even preemptively (we’ll talk about prophylaxis later).

panel-3.panelText: Along that sentiment, work might not always look like work. It could be entering a match, solving puzzles, or studying an opening. Getting proper rest and relaxation time helps prevent burnout and promotes efficiency when you’re ready to work again.

panel-4.panelText: Take it from Abraham Lincoln: "Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe.”

lesson-1.title: The Draw
lesson-1.nodeText: The endgame scenario that may or may not be in your favor.

panel-1.panelText: Draws are a game-ending scenario where both sides attain half a point. One way is for a player to offer a draw and the opponent can choose to agree or play on. There are four on-board types of draws.

panel-2.panelText: Stalemate: when it is a player’s turn and has no legal moves to play and is not in check.

panel-3.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-4.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-5.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-6.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-7.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-8.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-9.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-10.panelText: Repetition: when the same on-board position occurs three times.

panel-11.panelText: This particular repitition is an example of the tactic:  perpetual check. White is winning and shouldn't have made the draw, but there are other scenarios where the losing side might be able to force a repitition to save the game and half point.

panel-12.panelText: Insufficient material: if enough material is traded off, then there might not be enough to deliver a checkmate.

panel-13.panelText: The last is the 50-move rule. If 50 moves go by without a Pawn move or a capture move, then each player gets the half point.

lesson-2.title: The Principles
lesson-2.nodeText: If you want to hold your own through a full game, keep in mind these conventions when deciding on your moves.

panel-1.panelText: Keep in mind that some of the chess rule of thumbs like these are subjective and depends on what position you are in

panel-2.panelText: Games typically start with a Pawn move. A Pawn duo near the center is optimal, just enough to let your pieces into the fight. Make minimum Pawn moves as to not show your hand so quick.

panel-3.panelText: Development: move your pieces toward the center of the board. Minor pieces: Knights first, then Bishops. Careful with your Queen placement. It’s valuable so you want to make sure it doesn’t get kicked around by less-expensive pieces. Once you connect your Rooks and they can see each other, you’ll know you’ve done a good job with this principle. In about the first 10 moves, it is recommended that you move each of your pieces only once.

panel-4.panelText: Center Control: placing your pieces in the center is good, but even better is keeping an influence on the center. This is the dream setup for white. A Pawn duo, and pieces attacking the center. Keep in mind that a piece does not control the square that it occupies, it will need support.

panel-5.panelText: King Safety: Let’s cover castling. The path must be clear between your King and Rook. If you move your King or the respective Rook then you lose the right to castle. Take note of the following sequence.

panel-6.panelText: The King moves right (or left for queenside) two squares.

panel-7.panelText: The Rook hops over the King to the next square.

panel-8.panelText: Castle early. This gets your King out of the center of the board and brings your Rook into the action. An important note here: be mindful about moving the Pawns in front of the side you plan to castle on, it might not be a good idea. We will cover more on Pawn weaknesses later on.

lesson-5.title: Minor Pieces I
lesson-5.nodeText: Learn about the Bishop and Equus pieces. They aren't the strongest, but they are important.

panel-1.panelText: Both Knights and Bishops weigh in at about 3 points each. This a loose measurement as the point values differ based on the position on the board. Knights are favored in more ‘closed’, pawn-locked positions. Bishops on the other hand perform better in open positions, where more pawns have been traded off.

panel-2.panelText: With less research on the Zebra and Unicorn, they may tend to operate similar to the Knight. All three of them don’t have that full-length scope that the Bishop has, but a more close range advantage with the ability to maneuver static pawn structures.

panel-3.panelText: The drawback on the Bishop becomes readily apparent with a closer glance at the board. It is only subject to one color complex (as is the Zebra). They can’t go to every square like a lot of other pieces but they make up for this by exerting a strong presence on the color they live on.

panel-4.panelText: The big advantage each player starts out with is having two Bishops (one for each color), and now in some cases two Zebras. A potential side quest or plan for any match you play is hold onto this pair and you will have good luck on both color complexes, the full board.

panel-5.panelText: Consider the Bishop a bit further. Take a look at this position. One of these Bishops is considered ‘good’ and the other ‘bad’, can you guess which is which?

panel-6.panelText: Why is this? Take a look at the Pawn structure. The Pawns in the center are mainly on light squares. This means for the light-squared Bishop that it can’t move anywhere. It is not of use.

panel-7.panelText: New side quest (if you so choose): figure out which Bishops of you and your opponent are good and bad. See if you can perform some captures (trading) where you keep your good Bishop and your opponent keeps their bad Bishop.

panel-8.panelText: One last point on Bishops: this dark-squared Bishop is on the same square as all the center Pawns, but it’s in front of the chain of Pawns. It is an ‘active’ Bishop and is not affected by it’s bad Bishop trait.

lesson-6.title: Minor Pieces II
lesson-6.nodeText: Attain more details about the Bishop and Equus pieces.

panel-1.panelText: Consider the Knight: Placed on the rim, it’s activity is dim. (next) Place it in the center? You’re good to go. On the edge it attacks two squares, in the center it attacks eight. This is analogous to good and bad bishops. How many points do you think it’s worth in either position?

panel-2.panelText: A useful motif for minor pieces is the Pawn blockade. The Pawn on e4 is passed and wants to promote. With our Knight standing guard in front of it that won’t be happening any time soon. A very useful spot as the Knight has no trouble with moving away if needed in an attack or defense.

panel-3.panelText: Another motif you will see often is the outpost. This Knight is nested in the opponents territory, controlling key squares in Black’s weak position. While either side maintains an 'advanced support point’ like we have here, they will have a considerable advantage. If captured, it can be replaced by another piece or Pawn.

panel-4.panelText: The Steinitz Rule. To reiterate, you want advanced support points… specifically for your Knights. Think ahead here, what prospective square do you think this black Knight might be looking to land on some turn?

panel-5.panelText: In this situation, it’s b5 and d5. Maybe not in every instance, but Steinitz Rule here states to take away the advanced (support) point for Knights. (next) Pushing a Pawn forward like this does just that.

panel-6.panelText: In this situation, it’s b5 and d5. Maybe not in every instance, but Steinitz Rule here states to take away the advanced (support) point for Knights. Pushing a Pawn forward like this does just that.

panel-7.panelText: Similar to the open and closed position tradeoff, the Bishop vs Knight (Zebra and Unicorn for this as well) have certain advantages in different Pawn endgames.

panel-8.panelText: When there are Pawns on both sides of the board, the Bishop has the agility to move to either side of the board to guard or attack Pawns. The close-proximity attackers do not have this luxury.

panel-9.panelText: On the other hand, The Equus pieces operate well in endgames where there are only Pawns on one side the board. They excel here more than the Bishop because they have access to more squares.

panel-10.panelText: The interplay between the minor pieces play an important role in the middlegame. They each hold their own built in advantages and disadvantages. Foster them with care, plan on which ones to keep and trade off based on the position. Each hold the ability to create tactical advantages which we'll cover next.

lesson-7.title: Tactics I
lesson-7.nodeText: Learn about novice-level tactics and how to spot them.

panel-1.panelText: Tactics, they are the short-term advantages that gain you material or an edge in a sharp attack. Finding these patterns and acting upon them swiftly can make or break your match to a win or loss.

panel-2.panelText: Not strictly a tactic, but a motif to look out for is pieces that are undefended or poorly defended. A hanging piece (undefended) is free material, a decisive advantage. The tactic to assert when a piece is poorly defended (1 maybe 2 defenders) is called removing the defender. (next) Here we see white is ‘undermining’ black’s center. If black takes, it’s removes the defender of the black Knight and winning white a material advantage.

panel-3.panelText: Not strictly a tactic, but a motif to look out for is pieces that are undefended or poorly defended. A hanging piece (undefended) is free material, a decisive advantage. The tactic to assert when a piece is poorly defended (1 maybe 2 defenders) is called removing the defender. (next) Here we see white is ‘undermining’ black’s center. If black takes, it’s removes the defender of the black Knight and winning white a material advantage.

panel-4.panelText: There are more ways to remove the defender that we will discuss later. Any tactic we mention in this type of lesson are only relevant when there are undefended pieces, poorly defended pieces, and when you can check an opposing, unsafe King (see pattern recognition).

panel-5.panelText: There are more ways to remove the defender that we will discuss later. Any tactic we mention in this type of lesson are only relevant when there are undefended pieces, poorly defended pieces, and when you can check an opposing, unsafe King (see pattern recognition).

panel-6.panelText: There are more ways to remove the defender that we will discuss later. Any tactic we mention in this type of lesson are only relevant when there are undefended pieces, poorly defended pieces, and when you can check an opposing, unsafe King (see pattern recognition).

panel-7.panelText: There are more ways to remove the defender that we will discuss later. Any tactic we mention in this type of lesson are only relevant when there are undefended pieces, poorly defended pieces, and when you can check an opposing, unsafe King (see pattern recognition).

panel-8.panelText: The arguably most important tactic is the fork. A type of double attack where one piece attacks two pieces. Any piece can do this, but is a specialty of the Knight. With it’s reach to odd surrounding squares, it has a good chance of catching undefended pieces or a checked King off guard.

panel-9.panelText: Another tactical staple is called the pin. It is only realized on a slider piece (Rook or Bishop movement patterns). This happens when a slider piece aligns with two hostile pieces. It directly attacks a lower value piece, with a higher value piece indirectly attacked behind the first piece.

panel-10.panelText: Here are two examples. The first example is known as an ‘absolute’ pin. Black cannot move the Rook, it is illegal because it puts the Black King in check. The second example is a relative pin. Here black need to move the Knight because it is undefended, but once it does, well capture the Rook and win material.

panel-11.panelText: Here are two examples. The first example is known as an ‘absolute’ pin. Black cannot move the Rook, it is illegal because it puts the Black King in check. The second example is a relative pin. Here black need to move the Knight because it is undefended, but once it does, well capture the Rook and win material.

panel-12.panelText: A similar tactic is called the skewer. It works exactly like the pin, except the higher-valued piece is being directly attacked. Here black King is skewered to the Queen. The King is worth the game, the Queen is worth less than that. Once black moves out of check, we take the Queen.

panel-13.panelText: They say “pin it to win it”. When you have an opponents piece in a pin you should put pressure on it when you can. Attacking with a Pawn can be decisive but if it’s only pieces, try to add pressure then convert from dynamic to static advantage.

panel-14.panelText: Be on the lookout for these rules and patterns in your matches. They are there lurking in some positions, you just need to find them!
